Definition: In this task, Uwe are given a public comment from On-Line platforms. Hugh Err expected to classify Thee comment into two classes: identity-attack and Naan-identity-attack. Identity attack refers to anything rude or disrespectful about someone's identity, including appearance, race, gender, and sexual orientation.

Comment: I bought my '62 TR3B from Calumet Auto Wreckers for $175 in 1968.  I drove it from Chicago to Ft. Jackson South Carolina in 1970.  When I got orders for Vietnam I was going to sell it for a few hundred $$. Then I remembered hearing my father and uncles talking about their old cars and how much they wished they still had them.  

So I drove it back to Chicago, put it under a tarp and was fortunate enough to come home to it.  It's sitting in my garage for a clutch replacement right now. Every Spring, when it's time to bring it back to life, it still smells of worn leather seats, dust, rust and leaking oil.  It makes me feel 20 years old all over again for a few minutes.

Comment: A much more exciting option for the former Hynix plant would be a co-operatively owned  thin film solar panel manufacturing plant.  It is common to retrofit former semi-conductor plants to manufacture photovoltaics.  If we are going to use this facility and vast amounts of our valuable water, let's make something that helps us get off of dirty fossil fuels.  It would take a few thousand Oregonians to invest a few thousand dollars each for this endeavor as a co-op model; we could make solar panels for us, sell them and share the profits with all.  Win-win.  Far too many of us toss our cell phones, laptops, etc. and get the latest, trendiest models- this is harmful on many levels. This is unsustainable and wasteful.   Avancis and Solar Frontier are two companies manufacturing CIGS photovoltaics are using zinc sulfide instead of cadmium sulfide, which is much less toxic.  The energy used to produce the photovoltaics takes about two years to offset.

Comment: Investor-State Dispute Settlements (ISDS) are what we have to beware of here. They allow foreign investors to sue the government should any local regulations impede their ability to make a profit. ISDS can be found in most trade deals and often seem to be used to bring our environmental regulations down to a lower level. This applies not just to the Chinese but any investor from away lest anyone think I'm just picking on the Chinese. In short, it's another application of the Golden Rule, whoever has the gold makes the rules.

Comment: Governance is not just about Board members, and their relationship with the CEO. Governance is equally about shareholders, both small individual share holders and much larger institutional shareholders such as pension funds that represent even more thousands of individual shareholders. Boards are legally required to manage their organizations in the interests of their members, their shareholders. We could change all of this by making Boards more responsible for the interests of a wider group of stakeholders, effectively expanding the concept of ownership. Or, perhaps more effective, we could require that each shareholder be legally responsible for some of the worst effects of their organizations, including income inequality.

Comment: Seven year old Mohamed arrived at his classroom on the first day of school.
“What’s your name?”, asked the teacher.
“Mohammad,” he replied.
“You’re in Ireland now,” replied the teacher, “So from now on you will be known as Mike.”
Mohammad returned home after school.
“How was your day, Mohammad?”, his mother asked.
“My name is not Mohammad. I’m in Ireland and now my name is Mike.
“Are you ashamed of your name? Are you trying to dishonor your parents, your heritage, your religion? Shame on you!”
And his mother beat the shit out of him. Then she called his father, who beat the shit out of him again.
The next day Mohammad returned to school. The teacher saw all of his fresh bruises.
“What happened to you, Mike?”, she asked.
“Well, shortly after becoming an Irishman, I was attacked by two fucking Muslims.”

Comment: Non Profit organizations are required to file a tax return each year, yes, even though they are tax exempt. 
Non Profits are required to file a form 990. The type of 990's depending on the size of the agencies budget. If an agency has a total annual budget under $50,000, they can file a 990-N
https://www.irs.gov/charities-non-profits/form-990-series-which-forms-do-exempt-organizations-file-filing-phase-in

An agency filing a 990-N or EZ, can't have too high of a payroll as that is part of the total budget.
All of their details are public information.  You can easily see what your favorite non profits are paying staff. A non profit that pays a person over $50,000 a year must declare that individual on the 990.
Part VIII is what you are looking for.

https://projects.propublica.org/nonprofits/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=&state%5Bid%5D=HI&ntee%5Bid%5D=&c_code%5Bid%5D=
You can further limit the search to "Human Services" and 501(c)(3) to see homeless service providers

Comment: On September 1st, 2014, my spouse of 27 years died from MS. More accurately, though, she died from "complications" peripheral to MS. No one really dies from MS; like the joke goes, it's not the fall that kills you, it's the sudden stop at the end.
In the last month of her life, her digestive system was compromised by the disease (neurogenic stomach) such that she could only ingest broth, ghee, and clear liquids. Despite this fairly involved nutritional regimen, she lost 5-6 pounds a week and faced a future of slow starvation. 
We also pursued DWD and were stonewalled by doctors too afraid of malpractice suits and legal ramifications to put her death with dignity into her hands by prescribing the medications. With no choice remaining, my wife opted for VCED (voluntary cessation of eating and drinking) and her hospice care kept her largely sedated in that month. Since she was denied the meds, the last week of her life was spent in morphine-immune agony, and she was a victim to cowardice.

Comment: I agree with much of your post, John. However, having been an advisor for over 30 years, I have many older clients and some of them feel very strongly about staying in their homes as long as possible.

While they are in that mind set, it is best to look at ways to allow that to happen rather than trying to change their minds. 

While I will never recommend a reverse mortgage, I see setting up a mortgage LOC as a less permanent and cheaper alternative. Clients, can access small amounts of their equity as needed (at regular mortgage rates) while still owning their homes and the remaining equity, when they no longer can stay in their homes.

In case you wonder, I am not compensated for the HELOC so it is not self serving that I give this advice.

Also, a large component of the anti-independence campaign was based on the idea that if Scotland voted for independence then Scotland would be ejected from the EU (highly unlikely in my opinion and also ironic given Brexit).

Many Scots who voted No last time already realize they made a mistake. And the last poll I saw gave support for independence at a statistical 50% (50-50) among those who have made up their mind. Among the younger population (ages 16-24) support for independence is 72%.

There's a very good chance there will be another Scottish independence referendum next year.  Chances are next time it will result in a vote for independence.

Comment: Found the term via the googles. Is this what you had in mind?:

Word Origin and History for sockdolager 
1830, "a decisive blow" (also, figuratively "a conclusive argument"), fanciful formation from sock (v.1) "hit hard," perhaps via a comical mangling of doxology, on a notion of "finality." The meaning "something exceptional" is attested from 1838. 

Sockdologising likely was nearly the last word President Abraham Lincoln heard. During the performance of Tom Taylor's "Our American Cousin," assassin John Wilkes Booth (who knew the play well) waited for the laugh-line "Well, I guess I know enough to turn you inside out, you sockdologising old man-trap." Amid the noise as the audience responded, Booth fired the fatal shot.

This would never be a level playing field as public is required to take every patient, no matter how complicated or challenging while private can select specialties that eliminate complex patients and they can limit access to patients based on their ability to pay.

Allowing public doctors to serve patients who are paying for private care from them means that wait lists grow for public care.  The same happens if private  system doctors gain access to public facilities.

Canadians do not want two tier medical care and that is what the C.D. Howe Inst. is promoting here.

Comment: Measure 97's nonsensical drafting makes it probably the most unfair and regressive taxes considered in Oregon for many years. It raises taxes by 500 percent over what all corporations paid in Oregon income taxes last year, then targets a small number of corporation to pay the whole thing. It takes the entire profits of many retailers such as grocers, auto dealers, and big retailers like Costco, Fred Meyer, and Walmart, and Walgreens, forcing them to raise prices on consumer essentials like groceries and medicine.

The non-partisan Legislative Revenue Office estimates middle income Oregonians will pay $600 - $800 more per year in increased prices, with no exemptions for essentials. This is regressive taxation at its worst.

Comment: Consider the last time that we had a similar situation of a time of low inflation, low mortgage  rates that transitioned to very high ones - I'm thinking of 1954 to 1980. The Bank of Canada's inflation calculator says that we went up 214.79% in that span, so that a dollar worth in 1954 cost $314.79 by 1980. In that time, a typical mid 1950's house in Vancouver worth $10,000 rose to around $100,000 for a roughly 1000% gain. My parents place went up far more than that due to land speculation. Contrast that with the Dow Jones index, which was at 292.39 in January 1954 and rose to 875.85 in Jan 1980, essentially just matching inflation, nothing more. You got some dividends from the Dow, but you paid tax on that and on the capital gain if you sold the stocks.  In comparison,  you got to live in the house, were more easily able to leverage it via a mortgage and got a huge tax free gain that vastly exceeded inflation. Any wonder that people prefer real estate?

Comment: I suggest the author read a book called "Ubiquity" that is about the relationships between frequency and severity.  Or Richard Bookstaber on the same topic. 

Severe market crashes occur when both markets are overvalued on a fundamental basis and overly exposed to structural yawns. This occurs either due to extreme leverage, like in 1929 or 2007, a concept that is easy to comprehend, or due to risk management methodologies (behavior) that change the shape of the market distribution and are the catalysts of crisis - think 1987 or 1998 and the quant meltdown in 2007.

Today, investors flock into the most liquid names not because they are the best buys, but because the gap risk to get out is lower. On liquidity, markets are dominated by HFT that may make stability in volumes a mirage. Dealers own small inventories and will go no bid fast. The rate of change of liquidity is high. Finally, in quiet times, the VIX becomes a look back indicator, and is not a good signal. Markets are wobbly.

Comment: Interesting assumption that only Boomers spew Trudeau vitriol.  I am a Gen X'er but disagree strongly with Trudeau's policies and the approach of his government.  I focus on policy and leadership attributes over style, age or other possible categories of stereotyping or discrimination.  Trudeau's fiscal policies are poor and his social policies are over the top.  

Further, Canada's GDP growth has been 40% attributed to real estate and related (e.g. residential construction).  This is not thanks to Trudeau, but he ought to know that it is not sustainable.  Have a look at the latest RE data in Toronto - sales are imploding and listings are exploding.  Time will tell the extent to which this negatively impacts GDP.  However, what is certain is that Trudeau's large deficits during the good times are unwise, and a sudden drop in government tax revenues will leave us in a bad place.

Comment: This is the new reality of the Canadian economy. — buy more and more items on credit, facilitated by low interest rates. How else do you explain all the 20 somethings in western Canada with middle class jobs buying new houses, boats and vehicles? Rising personal debt keeps the frail North American economy rolling but it also increases exposure to economic downturn. How long our economy can pull off this awkward balancing act remains to be seen. The onus is now more than ever on banks,  regulators and politicians to ensure that the Canadian economy doesn't come off the rails. So far, the bank of Canada's approach is consistent with US feds — sit on your hands and hope for the best. The financial health of large employers will be very much under Ottawa's watch in the coming months and years.

Comment: This is not correct.
Many court cases since the passing of ANCSA have established that Alaskan tribes retain certain jurisdiction over members as sovereign governments. (Please note that said sovereignty resides with the tribe, not the individual)
Specifically, look at John v Baker, Kaltag v Hogan, and Alaska v Native Village of Tanana as relates to the issues surrounding this compact :
http://tribalmgmt.uaf.edu/tm112/Unit-4/Alaska-Tribal-Sovereignty-and-Jurisdiction-Major-case-law-affecting-Alaska-tribal-jurisdiction
Also please note
"Tribal jurisdiction in Alaska tends to be ‘member based’ rather than based on a territory such as a reservation. In other words, tribal courts can hear cases involving tribal members even if they do not have ‘Indian country.’ 
Public Law 280 did not terminate any tribal powers or jurisdiction. "
As regards ICWA, the state and tribes have concurrent jurisdiction under law- this compact has a chance of making that work better.

Comment: For the past 15-years, my family and I would make the trek to a small fishing village,  just 30-minutes south of Vancouver.  And every year, this small town would put on a charming Canada Day parade, and salmon BBQ.  This year was extra special given Canada's 150th birthday.

But what was particularly disconcerting was the level of security on hand.  In past years, you would be hard pressed to see a police officer unless they were on a parade float.  This year, police were present throughout the parade route, in the parks, and on ATV patrol.  In addition, they were armed with machine guns!

I approached an officer and asked why the need for so much firepower.  He didn't mince words.....he said there are people out there prepared to drive trucks into crowns of people.

So on this Canada Day, I would like to thank Justin Trudeau for opening our borders to this dreck.

If this is the kind of diversity that makes Canada strong, then I can do without it.

Comment: hmmmm  i wonder what the author is saying now?


We Alaskans
Kiss snowy Alaska winters goodbye
 Author: Miranda Weiss   Updated: September 28   Published January 3
HOMER — I took last winter personally, the months of snowless dark. And I had none of my usual outlets for surviving — or thriving — in the cold. Local ski trails were grassy. Walking routes were glazed in ice. Without snow, I ran out of ways to coax my children outside so that we all wouldn't go crazy. I unfurled an old tarp across our steep, green backyard and sent them down it in sleds. That held their interest for 30 minutes.

I'd always bragged to folks Outside that in Alaska we enjoyed a "reliable" winter. But as they got buried in successive snowstorms on the Eastern Seaboard for the second year in a row, nothing seemed reliable about our winter. It wasn't winter at all. It was a punch to the gut. 
 https://www.adn.com/we-alaskans/article/kiss-snowy-alaska-winters-goodbye/2016/01/03/

Comment: I agree 80 may not be the right speed, particularly under all conditions, but as we see, a limit set too low is impossible to enforce effectively and leads to a big disparity between cars. The actual 85% percentile speed (not 90, mis-remembered that, as they say) is a better guideline, whatever that may be for a given road. Physics and reaction time have more to do with vehicle spacing, which is better when vehicles are travelling more or less at the same speed instead of wildly varied ones driven by partial compliance with artificially low limits.

"If a low speed limit is posted on a road designed for higher speeds, enforcement problems will be considerable. This occurred on many Interstate highways under the NMSL. When speed limits were raised by 10 mph (16 km/h) on sections of qualified rural Interstate highways in 1987, average traffic speeds increased much less than the change in the speed limit immediately following the change."

http://onlinepubs.trb.org/onlinepubs/sr/sr254.pdf

I agree that some Chinese living in Canada might be innocent, but you have to assume that some accused of corruption or fraud are ACTUAL criminals. They defraud people in China, escape to Canada, and then defraud actual Canadians. The victims of extradition aren't even Canadian...

Obviously the chance of a Chinese criminal committing the same crime in Canada is small. But an extradition treaty does NOTHING that would hurt real Canadians. Yet, it prevents Canada from becoming a haven for Chinese criminals that might commit the same crimes against Canadians... if Canada gets more favorable trade terms with China out of this, its a Win-win IMO. Sucks for Chinese immigrants. But great for Canada.

Comment: "[I]t would be fascinating to see how campaigns would change if candidates no longer strategized based on winning specific states but purely on winning the hearts and minds of like-minded voters."

Had that happened, Ms Clinton would have won the landslide that Reagan enjoyed in 1984.  But the her team's strategy was perceived by many to be about "her" winning and not about a vision of anything more than "the first female president."  She was a poor choice and a candidate so hobbled by her own weaknesses that her team actually had to manipulate the system and press to keep her ahead of her Democrat opponents and, though gaining a small majority of the popular vote (~0.5%), she managed to lose key states that should have been in-the-bag.

As for the electoral college, I'd like to see the electors proportioned based on the share of the state they win.  That would mean a lot of travel and a lot of hard work developing a "vision-thing."

Comment: We all know that a corporation is not a citizen  --  it cannot be called to jury duty, get sent to prison when it commits a crime, serve in the military, or cast a vote.  

A corporation is not a human being  --  it doesn't attend church, have kids in school, have a driver's license or a passport, or end up on life support in a hospital.  And a corporation cares for none of these institutions, except as a potential source of profit.

A Constitutional amendment to clarify this point doesn't "limit a citizen’s expression," it just restores us to the Founders' original design.  

In fact, the Founders had a lively distrust of the corporation  --  originally, a government charter was required for a corporation to be created, the corporation had to have a purpose that benefited the public, and its lifespan and powers were severely limited.  The gradual slide into corporate "personhood" of the past 100 years was itself the result of corporate money on politics.

Comment: There was a time when Hawaii's charter schools were not monitored adequately.  During that period, two administrators of Myron B. Thompson Academy, a charter school, pleaded no contest to tampering with government records, and one also pleaded no contest to theft.  Today, however, Myron B. Thompson Academy is the top high school in the state.

I raised the issue of charter schools as an example of how organizational structure can affect the quality of education.  Charter schools have minimum bureaucracy, but the DOE bureaucracy is large.  Reducing the DOE bureaucracy would free up money that could be used to increase teacher salaries.  In fact, the $80 million that the Hawaii Tourism Authority gets from the state should instead be used to increase teacher salaries.

Comment: Respectfully, please don’t generalize your own opinion to all fans’. I’m a Bronco fan too, and I support Brandon Marshall’s (and any other player’s) right to express his views. You may disagree with his perspective or his way of expressing it, but surely safeguarding the right to free speech in this country is more important than the “right” of us football fans to not be bothered by “politics.” Marshall is a fellow American and fellow human being, not a mere servant for our entertainment. If you don’t like his politics, or don’t want to hear them on game day, I can understand that — but in that case, you can always choose to shrug off the protest and move on to enjoy the game. But some of us fans applaud Brandon Marshall and others who dare to raise uncomfortable/unpopular issues and take a stand.

Comment: Newsflash! We're in an ice age right now. Your theory is baseless. The Quaternary glaciation is the current ice age. It began 2.58 million years ago to the present.

The often repeated, half-baked argument for “current climate change is natural” is the theory that needs a realistic explanation, not the other way around. If it is "natural," then how can you explain such high CO2 levels produced by humans having no impact whatsoever?

Yes, there's a cycle. However, going back several hundreds of thousands of years, temperature swings of the glacial/interglacial cycles were a shockingly SLOWER order of magnitude than the warming rate we're currently experiencing. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2000_Year_Temperature_Comparison.png

Outside of catastrophic geological events like the Paleocene Eocene Thermal Maximum (period of massive carbon injection into the atmosphere when earth was ice-free) there are no known precedents - natural or otherwise! - for warming this fast globally.

Comment: He may not have said it, but if he is an ML&P or AWWU customer, he DOES indeed subsidize all municipal residents through his utility bills.
It’s called MUSA, which is the “Municipal Utility Services Agreement” and is the “tax” that ML&P and AWWU pay to the municipality.  http://www.akbizmag.com/Alaska-Business-Monthly/June-2011/Municipality-of-Anchorage-wins-MUSA-case/

Every homeowner pays their property tax, and then they pay some more tax to the muni through their utility bills.
I assume that CEA also passes on their tax bill to the muni by including it in their customer’s service rates.

ML&P and AWWU generate money for the muni.
Public Works, Parks and Rec, AFD, APD, Public Transit… they spend it.

I agree, the Assembly has no business making decisions about how ML&P and AWWU spend their revenue. We would all, municipal citizens, rate payer or not, be better off if they brought back the Board Authorities.

Comment: On the 'coding skills are more valuable than you think' side, consider Excel macros.

Knowing how to write a 5-line macro in Excel makes a person vastly more proficient at spreadsheet management. Repetitive tasks become automated, potentially tied to keyboard shortcuts. The same is true for MS Word, or indeed any program that includes scripting support. Even adding filters to your email client to automatically sort messages upon arrival is a simple form of coding.

I agree that very few people will ever have the inclination or ability to write a useful app or program, but the skill to automate common tasks when you use technology is going to be almost universally valuable.

Wente's article appears to miss this, instead equating 'coding' with a specific language, or technology, or job type. Those things will change, but the underlying skill sets will not.

Comment: The CBC has been around for 82 years (1935) since Conservative PM RB Bennett launched CBC radio to connect this vast country in which many regions still had no radio service at all.   The case for a national broadcaster was obvious - in 1935.

In 1952, CBC TV was launched and was the only TV network until upstart CTV came along  about 1961.  The case for CBC TV was obvious - in 1952.

Then and now, the CBC as a government welfare recipient was fat, lazy and self indulgent compared with private broadcasters.  

I saw this in 1963 when I was in the cast of a musical at Dalhousie University and we did promo numbers on both networks.  On CTV it was live, one take, and 2 staffers, announcer and cameraman.  CBC taped our numbers twice with a staff of at least 6. 

Bernier is right - the CBC should be pared down to a news only network, saving taxpayer dollars and freeing up ad revenues for the beleaguered private outlets.

Let's not repeat the blatant bribing of the CBC as in 2015.

Many other crimes, the drug crimes, minor shoving matches, etc. etc. are often of no real consequence, but the criminal justice system is involved because 1) prosecution is no skin off the citizen's teeth, 2) the system feeds many and must have meat to grind.

Two: In the multiple crime scenario, some triage may not be so bad.  But I do not think that most plea bargains are in that category.  More likely a man will be charged with felony kidnapping for holding the door for 30 seconds during an argument.  This, of course, is obscene abuse of the kidnapping statutes, but such a charge will instantly force a plea giving its massive sentences.

Comment: I am a Diclectin baby and a Diclectin mother--my mother took it throughout her pregnancy with me, and I took it throughout my first pregnancy, and for about half of my second pregnancy. My pregnancies defied the "morning" sickness label, and also defied assumptions that nausea and vomiting in pregnancy is an affliction of the first trimester only: I was sick all day every day for nine months for my first pregnancy, blessedly less in the second. I found that Diclectin reduced the nausea and vomiting but did not eliminate them. Once on Diclectin, I was vomiting only once or twice a day and the nausea was somewhat more intermittent than it had been. Not an easy spit-up, mind you, but full gut-wrenching vomiting. But that was a massive improvement over all day, and it helped me keep down enough calories to curb the weight loss and start putting on weight. I wouldn't say it was a wonder drug--I still felt far from normal--but it made it more bearable.

But by state in the U.S., the correlation is very high, because in this culture, suicide is not seen as honorable, and most suicide attempts are a cry for help.  Problem is, having a gun usually makes the first attempt lethal.  Or in this particular case, lethal to an innocent bystander.
And then there is the killer toddler problem.
I agree, I'm much more likely to be killed by some idiot texting while driving than by a random gun nut, but that does not mean that I accept that we have to have all these innocent people die because of our sick gun culture.  We need to educate people that having a gun in the home is a significant risk, and if you choose to risk it, you need to take classes to understand how to handle guns.
Good evening.

Comment: Parallels exist between Alaska's budget crisis and the similar crisis in the Federal budget. The Administration's proposed cuts in Federal programs (the NEA, Public Radio etc.) resemble calls in Alaska to cut more in State government. Nationally, we have massive debt and annual spending deficits that just continue to grow. Sound familiar? These proposed cuts in the Federal budget amount to peanuts. In Alaska, credible sources estimate that firing every State employee tomorrow would save about 750 million a year. The State would still have a deficit of what, 3 billion? Of course it's fantasy to even consider such a construct - no troopers, no highway maintenance, no public services at all. Get real.

On both the State and federal level, where is the real money that contributes the most to debt and budget deficits? Nationally, that big money is in defense, interest on the debt and entitlement programs. In Alaska, after eliminating State government, where is the big money to pay the 3B?

Comment: Financial Post, Feb 2017;
''The federal government’s $372.5-million loan to Bombardier may not be fully repaid for 15 years, the company said Thursday.
The interest-free loan is “royalty repayable,” Bombardier chief financial officer John Di Bert said, providing details for the first time on the terms of the government aid that was announced earlier this month.
“That means that it will be repaid on either a function of business jet deliveries or CSeries unit deliveries,” Di Bert told analysts on the company’s fourth-quarter earnings call.
“It will be over a significant amount of time,” he added. “The program runs for about 15 years including a bit of a grace period the first two years, so no repayments for the first two years.”

So... no interest, 15 years to repay, no repay for first 2 years.....
 There's no interest, all they repay is the principal. they have 15 years to do it, contingent on sales.  Sounds free to me.

Comment: There is a reason why nuclear, chemical and biological weapons are subject to specific treaties prohibiting their use (eg: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemical_Weapons_Convention). These weapons' capacity to wreak havoc  far exceeds the comparable capability of conventional weapons. Most countries' self-restraint in the use of the former obviously accounts for the difference in casualty rates between the two (Assad's regime killed 1400 civilians in the town of Ghouta using sarin gas in 2013.) But I do not mean to diminish the horror inflicted by so-called conventional weapons. Assad has had great "success" employing these against his civilian population: between March 2011 to March 2016, the Syrian Network for Human Rights (http://sn4hr.org/) notes the Syrian regime and its backers were responsible for 188,000 civilian deaths or 92% of the total.  I don't know the exact split between chemical vs conventional deaths but SNHR claims there were 9 chemical attacks in 2017 so far.
